qas.question: Where did smelting of iron begin?
When did the smelting of iron first begin?
When did iron making technology begin in Japan?
Pig iron is composed of iron and what else?
What makes Pig iron different from regular iron?
What smelting process was developed in 800 A.D.?
What technology arrived in Europe in 1800 BC
Where did iron technology arrived in 700 BC?
What was being produced in China in 1200 A.D.?

context: The first known smelting of iron began in <a0_0><b5_0>Anatolia<a0_0/>,<b5_0/> <a1_0>around 1800 BC<a1_0/>. Called the <b6_0>bloomery process<b6_0/>, it produced very soft but ductile wrought iron. By 800 BC, <b7_0>iron-making technology<b7_0/> had spread to Europe, arriving in <b8_0>Japan<b8_0/> <a2_0>around 700 AD<a2_0/>. <b9_0>Pig iron<b9_0/>, a very hard but brittle alloy of iron and <a3_0>carbon<a3_0/>, was being produced in China as early as 1200 BC, but did not arrive in Europe until the Middle Ages. Pig iron has a <a4_0>lower melting point<a4_0/> than iron, and was used for making cast-iron. However, these metals found little practical use until the introduction of crucible steel around 300 BC. These steels were of poor quality, and the introduction of pattern welding, around the 1st century AD, sought to balance the extreme properties of the alloys by laminating them, to create a tougher metal. Around 700 AD, the Japanese began folding bloomery-steel and cast-iron in alternating layers to increase the strength of their swords, using clay fluxes to remove slag and impurities. This method of Japanese swordsmithing produced one of the purest steel-alloys of the early Middle Ages.
